Notes:

See my Cura screen shot
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/e1OkXnkWL9D

It's an understatement to say that Anet A8's acrylic frame is weak...
Here is a carbon "exoskeleton" to add an incredible stiffness to your printer and thus reduce z-wooble caused by X axis shaking the frame.

I am an adept of KISS concept (Keep It Smart and Simple), you will need only one hour of printing to finish the exoskeleton which means very very few filament.

The stiffness is brought by 2 pieces of 6mm carbon rods or carbon tubes (go and search on ebay or in your local kite shop, you'll get them for less than $10).
If you don't get carbon rods, just use metal rods (steel or even aluminium) thy will do the job but in this case you need to add the middle junction pieces.

I join a not so good video explaining how to assemble it (sorry for the out of focus parts) https://youtu.be/Jiec6JPh0PI

I made it even stiffer just by adding a jonction piece where the rod crosses the vertical plate.

It worths to precise that those stiffeners do not interfere with the print area. the initial volume of 220x220x240 mm3 is fully preserved.

EDIT : you get also in a separate zip file all the STL to use with 5mm rods

I hope you like, any comment welcome ;-)

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm with a 0.4mm head

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Direct print with no support.

You will need:
. 3x M3x35 (on the top and middle left)
. 5x M3x25 or M3x30 (on the bottom and middle right)
. 8x M3 nuts

Bill of material
  • PLA
  • 2x 41,5 cm of carbon rod or tube with 6mm of outside diameter
  • standard M3 screws and nuts (I had some spare from the ANET box)
finishing the pieces

The ANET A8 is quite an accurate printer once properly built and trimmed.
I designed the pieces with very few tolerance especcialy at the level of the jonction of the carbon tube.
Once printed just manually drill the holes with a 6mm drill so that you'll need a hard push to insert them (just look at the video you'll hear the stick and slip noise...)

That's all you have to do !

warning

There is however a (small) drawback, you'll have to relocate the z-endstop for instance use this support : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2008349 .

The best way is to go to a z probe that has to be installed in front of the carriage.
Indeed, if you have installed a Z probe behind the X carriage (like the original anet's one) it may interfere with the carbon rods..

my other ANET A8 mods

If you like this mod for the ANET A8, you might be interested in my other ANET's designs all of them are here to improve the ANET A8 printer...

title: TARDIS Raspberry PI 3 case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I am setting up a linux desktop for my Son using a raspberry pi 3, but I wanted a meaningful case for him....

Since my Son really loves Dr. Who, I modified this TARDIS to allow the mounting of a pi3 inside it. Holes had to be cut into the right side to allow hdmi out, and the windows in the rear had the window panes removed to allow USB cables to exit. There are also 4 circular holes in the rear to allow you to place (optional) nuts for the screws to screw into.

There are two files now:

  1. "Tardis_PI3_case_1.stl", this is the original, as pictured in this thing. I have printed it and it works fine.

  2. Tardis_PI3_case_2_experimental.stl", this is the new version, the only change is that the side ports are enclosed around the top (power, hdmi, etc have no gaps around them anymore). This should make it look nicer.

comments.text:
Thanks for making this case, it looks really good. I ended up printing the experimental one, and just like Hauke, it work very well.
The empty space above the Pi, will be used to house the PiCam and possibly a motion sensor. Then I might print a 2nd one for the other Pi that controls my Arduino units via RF.

title: texas popper revisited
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
first of all thanks to icathcart for this nice lure.

i wanted to improve it a bit (from my point of view) and i fixed a few things on the model as well.

a few people reported slicer problems which were due to little gaps in the model and some areas with too thin walls. fixed all of that, so that you now can print the whole thing with the "mouth" down without any slicer problems or the need for supports.

additionally i introduced a channel from mouth to back and from top to bottom. i deeply mistrust those little screws in baits. especially as i like to use pla for those baits, because they will biodegrade at least within a hundred years or so if i loose them ;-) but if pla gets wet, it will be less hard, so screws won't hold. in the channels i can introduce a steel rod from front to back, on which i can mount hook and ring - this will definitely hold.

having already modified the lure, i also introduced a hollow chamber, in which you can input little marbles (2mm or so) to make the thing rattle... just stop your print at 50mm, which is layer 250 if you print in 0.2mm res. input your marbles and start again.

i haven't actually used my version up to now, but i will report, once i did. tell me how it worked for you.

author: FischOderAal

description.text:
Simple towel hook which clips onto the radiator.

Designed in two pieces to be glued together after printing. This gave better results than printing it as a single piece using supports.

I have not tested how well it works when the radiator is hot as it currently is summer.

If needed, the distance between two radiator tubes, the diameter of the tubes and the side of the hook can be adjusted.

Printer:

GEEEtech i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed using ABS on glass coated with ABS juice.
Nozzle temperature was 245 degrees Celsius. Bed temperature was 100 degrees Celsius.

Cleanup rough edges.

After printing any rough edges where trimmed of using a knife.

Drill a hole.

A small hole (3 mm) was drilled through the hook to allow excess glue to escape and to hold the hook during acetone vapor smoothing.

(The hole is not printed in case something other than ABS is used)

Glue the pieces together.

The pieces where glued together using filament dissolved into some acetone. Excess glue can escape though the hole.

Put the hook on a stick.

Push a stick or screw is into the drilled hole to hold the hook during acetone smoothing.

Acetone smoothing.

Using the stick to hold the hook, the hook is placed into a sealed pan with some acetone. The hook does not touch the pan or acetone.
The pan is then placed into a larger pan filled with some hot water.
The hook was left in there for about an hour occasionally adding some more acetone.

After an hour the hook was removed and left to dry overnight which gave it a smooth finish.

title: Raspberry UMPC
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update 08/09/17 : new raspberry Pi2 embox : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2514014

Le Raspberry Pi est un ordinateur miniature permettant la réalisation de nombreux projets, disponible dans le commerce dans sa forme la plus dépouillée, il se prête à l'intégration dans tout type de boitiers. Ainsi, l'objectif de ce projet, consiste à réaliser un nano ordinateur de la gamme UMPC (Ultra-Mobile PC) intégrant différents composants du commerce.
Il s'agit là d'un exercice d'intégration de composants du commerce permettant un exercice poussé de conception de boitier technique.
Attention : les modifications proposées peuvent être fatales à votre matériel. Ce projet est proposé "tel quel" sans aucune garantie de succès dans la réalisation et dans son fonctionnement.

Raspberry Pi is a miniature computer allowing the realization of numerous projects, available in several shops in its barest shape, it lends itself to the integration in every type of cases. So, the objective of this project, consists in realizing a nano computer of the range UMPC (Ultra-mobile PC) integrating various components.
This is an exercise of integration of components allowing an advanced exercise of conception of technical case.
Warnings : The proposed modifications can be fatal in your equipment. This project is proposed "as is" without any guarantee of success in the realization and functioning.

Rasperry Pi UMPC working : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2-fPb5VF1P4&feature=youtu.be

Pour réaliser ce projet, il faudra les composants suivants :
To realize this project, it will be necessary the following components:

  • Raspberry PI à partir du modèle B+, de préférence le modèle 3 (bluetooth et WIFI intégré),
  • Un micro clavier bluetooth du type ADK-100 Micro bluetooth Keyboard,
  • Un kit Adafruit Kippah sans contrôle tactile : https://www.adafruit.com/product/2454,
  • Le câble de connexion et son connecteur : https://www.adafruit.com/product/2098,
  • Un écran 5" : https://www.adafruit.com/product/1680,
  • Un booster chargeur de batterie : https://www.adafruit.com/product/2465,
  • Une batterie Li-ion 26650.
    Les produits Adafruit se commandent en France chez Mouser.com.

Préparation du Raspberry :
A faire avant toute modification du Raspberry : Préparer la carte SD du Raspberry en suivant les instructions proposées par Adafruit pour l'utilisation de la platine Kippah. Pairer le clavier bluetooth, paramétrer la connexion WIFI. Vérifier que tout fonctionne.

(Attention, cette intervention annule la garantie et peut détruire le Raspberry en cas d'erreurs)
Afin d'intégrer le Raspberry dans le boitier, il est nécessaire de le dépouiller de pratiquement tous les connecteurs dont il est pourvu. Pour ce faire, il est possible de suivre les conseils proposés par Adafruit : https://learn.adafruit.com/diet-raspberry-pi/steps.

Preparation of Raspberry:
To make before any modification of Raspberry : Prepare the SD card of Raspberry by following the instructions proposed by Adafruit for the use of the deck Kippah. Paired the bluetooth keyboard, parametrize the WIFI connection. Verify that everything works.

( Watch out, this intervention cancels the guarantee and can destroy Raspberry in case of errors)
To integrate Raspberry into the case, it is necessary to deprive it of practically all the connectors with which it is provided. To do it, it is possible to follow the advice proposed by Adafruit: https: // learn.adafruit.com/diet-raspberry-pi/st eps.

Il est ensuite nécessaire de raccourcir les pattes du port GPIO de façon à ce que, lors du montage de la platine Adafruit Kippah, l'ensemble ne dépasse pas 8,5 mm d'épaisseur. Il faut également rajouter deux port USB A en remplacement des modèles doubles présent d'origine.
Il est préférable de rajouter un radiateur sur les processeurs de la carte pour un meilleur refroidissement.

It is then necessary to shorten the legs of the port GPIO so that, during the assembly of the deck Adafruit Kippah, the set does not exceed 8,5 mm of thickness. It is also necessary to add two USB port A instead of the double models present of origin.
It's better to add a radiator on the processors of the card for a better cooling.

Clavier :
(Attention, cette intervention annule la garantie)
Démonter le clavier, dessouder la batterie (Attention danger de court circuit) de façon à dégager la platine électronique. Récupérer la platine, la membrane en caoutchouc et le cache. Voir photos.
Câbler la platine pour l'alimentation en 3,7 volts pris de la platine Adafruit Kippah. L'installer dans la partie imprimée puis sceller en faisant fondre les picots en plastiques. Placer la membrane puis le cache en force.

Keyboard:
( Watch out, this intervention cancels the guarantee)
Tear down the keyboard, unsolder the battery (Warning danger of short circuit) so as to release the electronic deck. Get back the deck, the rubber membrane and the mask. See photos.
Cable the deck for the supply in 3,7 volts taken by the deck Adafruit Kippah. Install it in the printed part then seal by melting teeth in plastics. Place the membrane then the mask in force.

Ecran :
Installer le connecteur et plier le ruban ainsi que le montre la photo. Coller l'écran dans le cadre imprimé avec de la colle contact en laissant dépasser le ruban de 3 cm.

Screen:
Install the connector and fold the ribbon as well as shows on photo. Stick the screen in the printed frame with some contact glue by letting exceed 3 cm the ribbon.

Batterie :
(Attention : respecter les précautions d'usage et manipulation des batteries Li-Ion qui peuvent prendre feu et exploser en cas de mauvaise manipulations)
Installer le power booster Adafruit et un interrupteur sur le couvercle de la batterie. Câbler l'ensemble selon le mode d'emploi proposé par Adafruit pour son module.

Battery:
( Warning : respect usual precautions and manipulation of batteries Li-Ion which can catch fire and explode in case of bad manipulations)
Install the power booster Adafruit and a switch on the lid of the battery. Cable the set according to the instructions proposed by Adafruit for his module.

Boitier :
Installer la batterie sur le boitier, passer les fils d'alimentation par le passe câble. Souder les fils d'alimentation batterie sur les pad 5V et GND du Raspberry.
Souder l'alimentation du clavier sur les pad d'alimentation proposés par la platine Adafruit : GND et 3,3v.
Monter la platine Adafruit sur le Raspberry. Installer la carte sd, connecter l'écran et Installer l'ensemble dans le logement prévu.
Installer le support de l'écran LCD : le pivot de la charnière est composé d'un filament plastique à imprimer. Installer le support de clavier en force.

Tout doit fonctionner lors de la première mise sous tension.

Pour ceux qui ne dispose pas d'une imprimante 3D, les pièces plastique composant ce kit peuvent être commandées sur Shapeways.

Case:
Install the battery box on the case, cross the wire of power supply by crosse cable. Weld the wires of battery on pad 5V and GND of Raspberry.
Weld the power supply of the keyboard on the pad of supply proposed by the deck Adafruit : GND and 3,3v.
Install the deck Adafruit on Raspberry. Install the SD card, connect the screen and Install the set in the planned housing.
Install the LCD screen: the pivot of the hinge consists of a plastic filament to be printed. Install the support of keyboard in force.

Everything has to work during the switched on.

For those who have not a 3D printer, parts of this kit can be ordered on Shapeways : https://www.shapeways.com/shops/modular_designs

description.text:
Se trata de la versión HULK de DYOR.

Hecho con Tinkercad. Edítalo online:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iTsHuPYDTLm

Por imposibilidad de fabricación en el tiempo previsto del modelo Hulk, se ha montado el modelo Darth Vader.

Vídeo del proceso de decoración, montaje y cableado:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fudxKk-StZk

El robot se ha programado con 2 modos de funcionamiento:

  1. Funcionamiento autónomo.
    El robot Darth Vader va circulando y al detectar un enemigo, se para, suena la música de Star Wars, la chest box emite luces, alza el brazo con la espada láser y arremete a toda velocidad contra el enemigo. Una vez derribado este, prosigue su camino.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SaxFR_unc2Y

  1. Control Remoto por Bluetooth desde una APP móvil realizada con APPInventor2, desde la que se pueden controlar todas las funciones posibles del robot, matriz LEDs, sonido, movimiento de ruedas y brazos, siguelíneas, detección de obstáculos...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_FtISuscEBM

Los componentes electrónicos y accesorios necesarios para llevar a la práctica el diseño que se muestra son los siguientes: 1 Arduino nano v3.0 y placa de expansión I/O Arduino nano 1 batería USB (powerbank) 2 micro servos de rotación continua FS90R y ruedas de 60mm 2 micro servos SG90 1 sensor de ultrasonidos SR-HC04 1 módulo seguilíneas TCRT5000 1 matriz de LEDs 8x8 (max7219) 1 zumbador pasivo (KY-006) 1 módulo bluetooth HC-06 1 rueda loca 1 cable usb Tabla de conexiones Esquema de conexión a Arduino Diseño en APP Inventor 2 Bloques en APP Inventor 2 Programación Facilino

MOOC UPV Diseña, fabrica y programa tu propio robot. DYOR Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x

description.text:
These are token, card and army organization items for the fantastic (but sadly out-of-print) Horus Heresy board game. It includes the following components:

  • Individual Chaos Army storage + lid.

Many of these models are customized versions of this hinged box. It's a great design!. Those containers with hinged lids can use a piece of 1.75mm filament as the hinge pin. I used a soldering iron to "fuse" the pin into the hinge.

These storage items should make setting up and tearing down go much more quickly, and they will all fit inside the box as well. They can also can be further enhanced and modified with the various chaos/imperial bits and badges you can find and print.

You will need:

  • 1 CD tray motor (usualy used for eject in PC CD/DVD drives)
  • 18 "VHS Tape" screws, or similar size... (2.5 x 15mm)
  • M3x40mm screw + M3 nut
  • 3 belts (from tape recorder, walkman,...) or printed. 36, 52, 51-52 (depends on CD motor belt pulley size)
  • Power source. I found USB-A male plug with easy voltage reduction as optimal solution (palm base has a hole for USB-A: 8x16mm) 5V USB Adapter / powerbank can be used.
    CD motor is running from 1.2 to 2.6V (about 30-90mA). In a palm trunk is a space for few 3-4 diodes to reduce USB voltage. I'm not proud of this solution, but switched DC-DC converter for 30-90mA is a waste of money.

Main Wheel has two versions:
1) with VHS screw, but part with the birds is connected only with thin piece of plastic!
2) with M3 screw through axis & nut on the upper side (safe version)

I needed a way to attach my 32" display to a 2040 extrusion since it did not come with any feet. The mount slides down the 2040 and is attached using M5 T-nuts. The mount holds its weight but will slide when you mount something to it. The large hole is for a M8 screw commonly found as mounting screw for larger VESA compatible displays.

Two versions are included, one for M8 screws and one which fits a M8 nut, if you need to mount something the other way around

I only used two M5 screws with T-nuts on each side, but you can fill out all holes if you like.

I used 25% infill and seems strong enough for modern displays. I printed using PLA but would recommend PETG or ABS for heavy screens.

title: PLONK the Plucky Little Bearing Tool

description.text:
I wanted to use the X-Idlers by Leo_N; https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1919544 So, naturally I had to install new bearings or reuse the old ones. He suggested centering them in the idlers; and included a tool to do this in his files. I later found using it to be problematic in several ways. So, I whipped up this little hellcat.

PLONK can install and center LM8LUU bearings by design, but should work with most 9x24/45 bearings regardless of material. The text while quirky, also serves as a gripping surface. PLONK wont damage bearing housings and install/centering is quick and easy. I suggest at least 8 shells and 100% infill when printing. If so, PLONK will be a staple in your printers' tool kit for a long time. I will design an add-on for this to remove bearings as well, and update when possible. Thanks to Leo_N for his great designs and community support! Happy PLONKING!

Use: Center PLONK in the bearing using the centering rod. Hammer the bearing till flush with the parts' top, or until top handle is flush with idler top to center bearing in Idlers.

For a dynamic duo use in conjunction with THWONK; https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34404

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iqFvOI1uAup
Bring your cookie making to the factory level with the Cukie Cootter! Simply select your cookie size, print, slide on your kitchen roller and get the cookie cutting started.

This thing is like having a bunch of cookies cutters wrapped around a roller that can be slided over your kitchen roller. Can also be used for dumpling, pasta, modeling dough, soft chocolate ... and even pizza, if you manage to print a big one. Easy way:
1- Print the STL file. This can make cookies of 70mm (2.76 in.) in diameter
2- Slide on you roll (it must be 50 mm (2 in) in diameter or less)
3- Roll over your favorite cookie dough Custom way: (OpenScad needed)
1- Enter your parameters in the SCAD file, render and print.
Parameters: Cookie diameter and thickness, Size of roller used (add an extra 2-3% to compensate for shrinkage), number of cutter around the roller, thickness of the plastic, resolution.
2- Slide on you roll or adjust with sanding paper if it doesn't fit.
3- Roll over your favorite cookie dough. Looking to improve on this thing? Possible improvements (in order of difficulty):
  • Add some features in the circles to add textures to the cookies. (+1 fashion point)
  • Build a larger roll to cut many rows at the same time. (+2 speed pts)
  • Make other cutter paterns (+3 fashion pts) (An Escher patern whould allow for a remains-less cutter (+1 ecolo pt))
  • Make a script able to wrap any image around the roller. (+10 fashion pts, +5 programing pts)
    • Good cooking!

Wear your Garmin Edge 25 on your wrist with this mount. The mount uses Garmin's 90-degree twist.

The Edge 25, of course, is meant for tracking bicycle rides. You can wear it on your wrist for this use. However, you can also wear it while walking or jogging. While this won't count your steps, it will provide you with total distance, average walking speed, etc. It also provides you with the time of day!

Update 15-Jul-17: I updated the file with some minor improvements. This version looks a bit less 'clunky' on the wrist!

Note: I have been printing the EDGE 25 wrist holder at 108 percent. On my Makerbot 2, it has too much interference at 100 percent--perhaps due to the surfaces not being as smooth as desired.

print_settings.Notes:: You'll want to have good support settings for this one. I get great results with five layers of dense support close to the part and a one layer gap. Simplify3D has a setting for this, I assume Cura probably does, too.

description.text:
This is a fidget spinner that you can both roll and turn with your hand as well as roll between your fingers. It's fun! It's just shy of 3" diameter when spinning, takes a 608 bearing, and uses 9/16" individual ball bearings as counterweights. You can spin it in your fingers, but don't let that hamper your creativity -- my toddler likes to use it as a top!

I wanted a spinner that I could roll between my fingers, so I started with pads that form a sphere, and then modeled a spinner around the pads that would preserve the entire sphere as much as possible.

Too small in diameter and you lose angular momentum and the feedback you get when you roll it. Too large and it'll bump your hand. This is a good balance between range of 'rolling between your fingers' and amount of angular momentum.

I've also uploaded a version of the body without the cutouts for the bearing balls -- if you'd like to try it without using the balls as counterweights, download this one!

Designed and rendered in Fusion 360.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50 - 100%

Notes:

You'll want to have good support settings for this one. I get great results with five layers of dense support close to the part and a one layer gap. Simplify3D has a setting for this, I assume Cura probably does, too.

Press in bearings and pads

The pads are designed spot on at 8mm in diameter to insert into a 608 bearing. The spinner body bearing hole is 22.2mm diameter (.2mm oversized). I use my bearing press tool and can get them in by hand usually, sometimes by foot.

Originally designed for Tevo's titan extruder, but it should fit any titan extruder.

I didn't like how far the extruder sticks out with the original mount so I designed my own. It is loosely based on the original mount. The center plate is shifted so that the small stepper motor is flush at one side. The extruder itself sticks out only a little now.

The second version with "Cable" included in the name has a little cutout to allow rotation of the motor and let the cable be routed straight upwards or downwards.

UPDATE: In addition to these two versions there is now a third version available which can be mounted on a 2020 extrusion. This one is held in place on two sides.

Enjoy!

title: Prusa Haribo 3030 Rambo and raspberry pi3 mount

description.text:
This is a remix of Aaron Yourk's design for the rambo mount for the prusa mk2 upgrade, "Haribo", which is a 3030 frame replacement (as seen here: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/58SFoYa8hJq-mk2-x-carriage-cable-chain ).

I wanted the bottom of the mount stablized, as well as a place to mount my pi3, which I use for print spooling. I also did not need the multi-color module (PT100), so that has been removed.

With the pi3 so close to the rambo, you can link the two together with this super short usb cable: http://amzn.to/2sNxG7e

The X carriage chain mount has been modified to be skewed to the right to allow for extra clearance. There are also zip tie holes through the arm to allow for zip tying the wires (cable routing). Finally, without the multi-colors module, I was able to relocate the mount point further forward, which means the arm could be much shorter than before. Shorter arm means less flex.

title: Carbon Fibre Tube Quadcopter - Kraken Pod

description.text:
UPDATE: Both V1 tube frames have been broken due to the carbon tubes not being properly secured and reinforced. I am working on a second revision that will use two small carbon plates to reinforce the arms, rather than relying on a big blob of epoxy.

Inspired by the Bexamous tube frame: https://imgur.com/a/hEevI

Final frame weights:
5" 200 size - 43g with a 2mm Kraken pod (31g without)
6" 230 size - 55g with a 3mm Kraken pod (34g without)

To make a frame you will need:

4x 10mm_tube_16mm_mount (the part the motors mount on to)

1x 10mm_tube_Kraken template (this part is used as a template for drilling the board and pod holes and filing the notch)

10mm OD, 8mm ID carbon fibre tube, length of your choosing. I get mine here: http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/1Pc-Roll-Wrapped-Carbon-Fiber-Tube-3K-8mm-x-10mm-X-500mm-For-Multicopter-DIY-/131665162489?hash=item1ea7daf0f9:g:i3MAAOSwNphWXWZJ

Epoxy, I used 5 minute epoxy.

Optionally, a Kraken pod, I find the 3mm pod to be indestructible but the thinner pods are much lighter. I'm currently working on my own TPU pod that will fit a 50x50mm mounting pattern. https://boltrc.com.au/index.php?id_product=162&controller=product&search_query=kraken+pod&results=15

How to put it all together: (Repeat steps 1,2,3,4. You will need to make two tubes)

NOTE: Carbon fibre dust is not good, avoid using rotary tools such as a dremel tool because it will throw dust in the air. A drill, hacksaw and a file are all that will be needed for the build and are all safe to use as long as the carbon is kept wet. I cut and drill my carbon outside spraying the tool and carbon tube with water frequently.

Tools:

Hacksaw
Drill
File
Water proof fine sanding paper (optional)

  1. Measure
    Measure a section of carbon tube, wrap the area to be cut with masking tape. For reference, I use two 250mm long tubes for a 6" and 220mm for a 5", both fitting a Kraken pod.

  2. Cut
    Cut the tubing as desired with a hacksaw, keeping the tube and saw wet so no carbon particles escape. You may have to roll the tube around to make the cut. If the end of the tube is left rough or uneven wet the sand paper and smooth out the tip of the carbon tube.

  3. Drilling
    Slide the template block on to a tube, lining the middle of the notch up with the centre of the tube. Place a motor mount on each end of the tube, ensuring that the end of the tube is level with the end of the motor mount. Ensure that both mounts and the template are correctly placed, you don't want misaligned holes. Drill a small pilot hole through all holes on one side of the tube, I use a 1/16 size bit. Repeat on the other side and follow up with a larger drill bit to widen the original holes so that they can all fit a M3 bolt. (Using a pilot hole minimises splitting of the carbon.) Wet the tube and drill bits as required.

  4. Filing
    For this task I use a 4mm wide file that is about 200mm long. Wet the notch and file and begin to wear at the exposed carbon in the notch with the side of the file. remove all carbon from the notch and attempt to make the edges as smooth and straight as possible.

  5. Assembly
    Remove the template and place all motor mounts on the ends of each tube, lined up with the holes. Notch the two carbon pieces together and check they will fit smoothly and correctly. Begin to mix the epoxy. (I use a broken prop for this, actually very good for scooping up a little bit of epoxy and applying it.) Coat the edges of the exposed notch on each tube with epoxy, Apply epoxy to the gap between arms at the centre of the frame as well as the top and bottom of where the notches meet. (Bexamous' guide has pictures detailing this process and shows how much epoxy should be used) To make sure the frame comes out straight I like to flip it over so the mounting surface of the motor mounts is upside down, then I screw on a Kraken pod to make sure it holds a good X shape. Allow the epoxy to cure for at least about 12 hours, preferably in a warm dry place.

2017-11-22:
Rear Idler Right is BROKEN. Left is fine.

2017-11-06 update:
Changed most parts on my printer for the remodelled ones, seems to work great.

Re-modelled in Fusion360 for easier modifications.
http://a360.co/2sNiTcD

Parts I've printed that seem to be 100%:
Everything

Parts that I've fitted to my machine:
None

Export STLs from bodies in Fusion360.

Should be identical or functionally identical, if you find an error somewhere, please let me know.
Only printed the extruder so far, as that is what I was the most unsure about, seems to work great.
Please note that I have not added the 'notches' in the parts, as they are undesirable when using t-nuts, which I am.
Made 300x300.

E3D Model from
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:341689/#files

V-Wheel model, 2020 and 2040 profile models from Openbuilds.

No reason to use these STLs unless you plan to modify with them as a base, use the original instead if you just want stock D-Bot.

remixed_from.title: OpenSCAD ISO metric thread library / functions (updated)

description.text:
I've found the great Intex Pool Vacuum Adapter by mredmon and I was inspired so I changed a bit of his openscad file and printed it. But, hey, the thread was different (some mm bigger) than my Intex outlet thread! So I started a new model rewritten from scratch.
I've optimized several things of his already great design:

  • Correct size and thread pitch (for my Intex pool, at least!)
  • a better thread: the thread don't start and stop in a visible way inside the thread (as the ISOThread library is doing)
  • I've used the ISOThreadUM2 by Trevor Moseley (thank you!) that resolve the problem that the thread is composed by many small bits. Using Cura to slice they where all small islands, very bad to print!
  • I've made the hose adapter base smaller so that the cone has a constant wall thickness. Less filament to use and faster print.
  • The knurled surface is complete (this is about taste, I liked more this way)

Please check your thread dimension if it's the same as the design as it seems that Intex has different sizes.

You can find the ready to slice STL or the original OpenScad file, if you want to tinker with it. In that case remember to download the two scad libraries in the same folder as they are needed to render.

Printer:

New Matter MOD-t

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2mm layer

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I've used supports only for the small cavity on the top of the hose connector. All the base and cone don't need supports (check to not use it there).

Check your XY expansion. I had to use -0.3mm in Cura 2.6 to compensate my printer extrusion. In theory a correctly calibrated printer should print it with 0 XY expansion without issues but I have no way to check it as I cannot calibrate my printer.

O-ring

I've used a size 8 o-ring for the hose connector, taken from a kit of o-rings bought on amazon for 18€.

I've designed this using OpenScad. The idea comes from the model I've remixed this from but I've writed all fram scratch.
I've used two libraries (that you need to have in the same folder as the main openscad file):

  • ISOThreadUM2.scad (wonderful thread library originally written by Trevor Moseley and optimized by JustKrys on youmagine)
  • knurledFinishLib.scad (a wonderful library by aubenc here on thingiverse to generate knurled cylinders. Very heavy to render but effective to have more grip!)

A triangle to connect ply wood together. My daughter told me that she want do a tablet holder.
So she took a ply wood and cut the boards with a coping saw in the right size. The first try to glue the sheet of ply wood goes really wrong. So the next step in processing was calling dady [long accent on y] We develope the idea to do an universal connector for the ply wood. After some tests we found that a small triangle would fulfill our requirements.
The triangle has 2 inserts to put in the the ply wood sheets:
For better connecting we used a super glue how to join the pla and the plywood sheet. http://www.indoor-hydroponic.org/?page_id=246

title: Abloy 342 and 362 Padlock Protective Lock Cover

description.text:
The Abloy 362, especially with a Protec2 core, is one of the most unpickable padlocks made, with no one having been able to pick one on video, even with special $300 tools. With its 15mm shackle, it cannot be cut with bolt cutters. If you freeze it with liquid nitrogen and hit it with a sledge hammer, it won't break.

But the lock is so nice, that it is close to too nice to actually use. This protective cover should help keep it from getting scraped up on pavement.

Note that this lock won't even fit through 3/8 inch chain and most hasps, so make sure you can pass 15mm for your application.

If the fit is too loose, then wrap a piece of electrical tape around the lock first, and then the fit should be snug. If you want to remove the cover, loop a belt around the shackle and something fixed, and then pull on the cover.

Medieval defensive anti-cavalry tile with openlock connections. Also known as Cheval de Frise. They were principally intended as an anti-cavalry obstacles but could also be moved quickly to help block a breach in another barrier. These could be moved and anchored in different locations to prevent cavalry charges or attacks at certain locations. It is a pretty good tile for war game type play by adding more obstacles.

This is a 2 inch by 2 inch tile that is able to be connected using the openlock clips found here to other openlock tiles. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963

description.text:
A Fidget Spoon! Similar to a fidget spinner, but with 'spoons' on the ends. Put a bearing in the middle. (Your bearing may not fit in the middle. This is designed for an about 22 mm bearing diameter. You can scale it up or down if you need to change the size.) Then, put 2 pennies in each of the 3 spoons to use as weight. Spin away! I got a 1-minute spin time with an old bearing, so it spins well!
If you would like a Fidget Spoon already printed with bearings and pennies in it, you can go to http://www.92spoons.com/products/fidget-spoon
Note: The Fidget Spoon and the caps for it print much better upside down because the supports are cleaner and look better when finished, so you should use the upside down file. I recommend using concentric supports.

comments.text: Using concentric supports and printing everything upside-down makes the supports easier to get out and makes the thing look better when assembled.

title: Epic Scale Astartes Tactical Proxy - low poly

description.text:
A Space Marine Tactical Marine proxy model for Epic scale games (40k or armageddon etc).

[update 20171027: have managed to netfabb all my 'recentish' files so everything back to the knights basically. including these chaps. plus new file or two added and everything renamed a bit as well.]

[update 20170909: added 'no weapon' model for use as pilot/gunner etc]

This is a reworking of the fractalnoise tactical space marine (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:620555) as a low-poly model. The fractalnoise marine is truly one of my favorite models and i've printed hundreds of them for my armies. (in a burst of 'that would be right' i'm pretty much done printing my armies now that i've finished the variants [sigh].)

i wanted to be able to repose them for another project, and thought i may as well drop them in here too.

note: the imperial guard infantry model (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2413170) was the first of this series. tactical is the second release. termis will be third. then some orks, necrons and chaos a bit later.

testing pics: the A,B, C was me testing my models against the original. A is the original fractal stl, B is my remake and c is the guardsman to test scale. A and B are effectively identical on a low-res printer. so 5 by 5.

the yellow marines have new sergeants using the new poses.and so far i have managed to curb the ocd and not add in new poses for everyone else.

So all in all this was a quick and easy model i made after the skyward sword logo with some insperation from the triforce logo of wind waker.

Recommend to use 1.2mm stand width on really upscaled or downscaled prints. As the big models you might have a weight issue with 0.8 mm supports between the parts not being able to hold up.The small prints may have problem printing 0.8 down scaled. But else the 0.8mm looks better. I added files without support between the parts incase you want to glue it to something and a model with no base incase you want to hang it on the wall.

Send me a message on thingiverse if you got any constructiv critism i appriciate it.

Sorry for bad grammar. I am norwegian and not to skilled with english yet.

Printer:

Cr-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.05

Infill:

5

Notes:

I took 0.05mm resolution just to see how it turns out probably fine using 0.2 or less. i had 5 top layers because its 0.05 res. if you are going with higher res 2-3 layers should do it.
I desinged this in fusion 360 and made a short local render of the model.

comments.text: Nice model! I've printed the 0.8mm one a little bit upscaled (170-200%) at .05mm resolution. I honestly think it's too hi-res for this model, as it took 9+ hours to complete, and the resulting model it's not very large. Also, I had a problem with the last layer of the crest itself: the layer is not completed and there are some small holes. I think it's because of the resolution and because my printer didn't perform brilliantly. Also, maybe I should have slowed my printing speed a little bit, but it was 400mm/s so it wasn't too fast... Overall, nice model, and I would appreciate if you could put some more instructions in order to get the best print quality possible with the parameters you think are the nicest. Thanks!
comments.author: mgl1998

comments.text: if you are printing with 0.05 layer height you should have 24 top layers to get rid of the holes (also depending on the infill, with higher % the less you need in amount of layers. The formula i use to calculate the max required top layers is 1.2/layer height with a 0.4 nozzle but this is for like 0% infill to 4%). and 400mm/s is insane your printer is most likely not allowing you to print that fast. try 200 to see if it even makes a difference.

title: Bumper Case for Moto G5 Plus

description.text:
Today I’ve got something hot off the printer for all you Motorola Moto G5 Plus owners out there. I’ve been working on a bumper case for my Moto G5 Plus and after a number of design iterations I’m now really happy with it and it’s ready to share with all of you G5 owners. I've used a minimalist look while still making it easily printable. It's designed to protrude slightly on the front and back to absorb any knocks, scratches and impacts... plus it let's your phone cool down much better than a full case will :)

I made a quick showcase video on the bumper here:-
https://youtu.be/1zLvlf0-j-k

I’ve also made combined car and desk stands in two different styles that are made to fit this bumper case perfectly:-
landscape version:- https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430666
Portrait version:- https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430687

Fitting to your phone is easy, just put the end in first and then on a flat surface push down on the top until it snaps firmly on.

You can check out my other designs here:-

https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Supports are needed as this should be printed with the rear of the case facing up just as the STL file appears. The reason it's not the other way around is that the detail on the back will likely be blemished by any supports.

I now mainly use Simplyfy3D to slice for three main reasons;-

  1. the supports come away beautifully and
  2. for items that rely on tight tolerances (like this case!) it prints the most accurate that I've used and
  3. You can specify different print settings in a print so for sections with detail you can reduce layer height and for uniform sections you can increase it and get great looking prints done fast!

I suggest printing with 4 perimeters and 25% infill as there's only a handful of grams of plastic in this so don't skimp.

I suggest printing this in an improved PLA (see below) or other filament that's strong and tough.

Beware: Not all PLA's are made equal.

Most of my prototypes and a good proportion of final prints are with an 'improved' PLA from Esun called PLA Plus (sometimes called pro) and it's tough and definitely not brittle and it's really cheap too. Some other moderately priced improved PLA's I've used are Filamentum, Prusa Brand & Colorfabb Economy PLA.

I haven't tried Hatchbox, Matterhackers, Taulman InPLA and Filaform Pro PLA but I hear some good things about them.

I also use a few better quality name brand PLA's for special one off jobs like phone cases and these are quite a bit better than the Esun though up to triple the price... though bare in mind this print in the pricey filament would still only cost a couple of bucks.

For the best looking prints with a fair bit better toughness than the Esun I use either Polymaker PolyMax PLA or ColorFabb PLA PHA. If excellent toughness and strength is a priority then the Polymaker PC Max polycarbonate is the one I'll always reach for and the finish is still good too.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/1zLvlf0-j-k" ></iframe>

comments.author: Ucent

comments.text: Thank you for making this design but mine cracked when I tried to put it on the phone, at the mic hole. Any suggestions?
comments.author: 1911kevin

comments.text: Hi Kevin, sorry to hear that. You probably did it right but just to be sure, the bottom of the phone needs to be slid in first and then the top snaps in second. I've done this a few times to my phone and the case is still completely intact. The video I added shows me doing it. The next reason may be that your PLA might be a bit brittle. PLA takes on moisture in the air so drying it out might help or else try a different PLA you've had success with. Another issue might be over-extrusion giving you thicker walls - hence a tighter fit. You can adjust the extrusion multiplier for this... to get the correct multiplier I do a 1cm (0.9mm wall) hollow open top cube to test the wall thickness and then divide 0.9mm by the thickness to get the correct multiplier. Hope some of this has been helpful. If not post some more details and I'll try to figure it out for you?
comments.author: 1911kevin

comments.text: Thank you I'll give those suggestions a try!

description.text:
Today I’ve got something hot off the printer for all you Motorola Moto G5 Plus owners out there. I’ve been working on a landscape stand to fit perfectly to my new bumper case that I designed for my Moto G5 Plus.

After a number of design iterations I’m now really happy with it and it’s ready to share with all of you Moto G5 owners.

I made a quick showcase video on the mount / stand here:-
https://youtu.be/QDvo3Ak01_M

The matching bumper case that fits this stand and the Moto G5 Plus can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430653

There's also my portrait version of this stand here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430687

I designed the stand with a minimalist look that fits flush with the bumper & phone. This stand will work great on a desk or nightstand and the usb plug is still accessible for charging. I also designed it so it can be mounted onto the centre air vents of most cars. The added benefit of mounting it on the vents means that your phone is kept from overheating by the cool vent air. The stand was successfully tested on an older model Nissan as well as a late model Honda and Suzuki.

You can check out my other designs here:-

title: MK9 Extruder Z-Axis Induction Sensor and Fan Bracket

description.text:
This is a remix of the Thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1267183.

There are versions of this bracket for 12mm and 18mm sensors.

Marlin firmware offsets for the 12mm sensor bracket:
X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -33 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -8 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]

Marlin firmware offsets for the 18mm sensor bracket:
X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -37 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -4 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]

This remix is 1mm thicker on the back, so the extruder fan won´t touch the extruder heatsink.

There are two variants of this design. One has only plain holes for the fixating screws to pass through it, and another with M3 nut slots on both sides. This second version will allow a more firm fixation to the screws.

Enjoy.

11/07/2017 - Files included.

title: Liu Hui Cube Puzzle/Dissection (Qiandu, Yangma, Bie'nao)

description.text:
The cube can be dissected in multiple ways. There is one well-known dissection that decomposes a cube (or any rectangular prism) into its half, third, and sixth, using two simple face diagonal cuts. The idea dates back all the way to around 263 AD when a famous Chinese mathematician, Liu Hui, illustrated the idea in his commentaries on the Chinese Nine Chapters of Mathematical Arts.

Liu Hui’s dissection can be easily accomplished in a modern 3D design environment such as Autodesk Fusion 360® or similar packages. Take a cube. Slice it along a face diagonal. We get two halves. Each half is called a “Qian Du,” using its original Chinese name. Keep a half piece and slice the other along another face diagonal. We get a square pyramid, which is one third of the cube and is called a “Yang Ma.” The third solid is a tetrahedron, which is one sixth of the cube and is called a “Bie Nao.” It makes natural sense that two halves (Qian Du) make a cube and three Yang Ma make a cube. The Bie Nao are a bit unique. If we take two Bie Nao and make a mirror image of one of them. The two Bie Nao would make a Yang Ma. Therefore, if we take six Bie Nao and mirror three of them, we could make three Yang Ma and further a whole cube. It is fun to explore the visual, spatial, and quantitative relationships among these pieces.

For printing, 0.2 mm is just fine. If you choose 0% infill, you could leave some small magnets inside, when the pieces are half way in the printing process. Please increase shell to 4 if the walls are too thin.

For more information, please refer to

Bu, L. (2017). Exploring Liu Hui’s Cube Puzzle: From Paper Folding to 3-D Design. MAA Convergence. Accessible at ttps://www.maa.org/press/periodicals/convergence/exploring-liu-hui-s-cube-puzzle-from-paper-folding-to-3-d-design

Printer:

FlashForge

No

0.2mm

0% infill makes the solids hollow; please increase the shell/wall thickness if necessary. Small magnets can be placed inside each piece about half way.
Nothing really. Just have fun!

author: angelinama

description.text:
All Evil Genius/Mad Scientist wannabes need an assistant - introducing E-Gor! A remix of the Chip-E kit from Robotgeek.

Having a lower back injury which limits my sitting, standing, etc, also limits other things. like how long I can spend drawing designs or documenting them. E-Gor can't help with that. But checking how well the Roomba is cleaning, looking for the cat toys (of which there are many), recovering crashed drones (<100mm) - he can and does for me. And has a small cart to push my drink around too.

The first thing that is needed is actually a fix to the build instructions. Step 6 in the Getting Started Guide (Tuning Chip-E) is basically a trial and error process and there is nothing wrong with such a process but you you need to start from a reasonable position. Any good Evil Genius (oxymoron?) knows you don't begin building a nuke by taking a cube of plutonium and putting a stick of dynamite in it. So I took the wonderful Otto Calibrate code that J. Lopez Verdejo wrote and adapted it to Chip-E as well as translating the menus to English. Just upload this code to any Chip-E and run it with the Serial Monitor open. Be sure to set the correct baud rate and carriage return. Type a ? for help at any menu. I use the edge of a metal ruler across the feet and along the back edge to get a good base line. Adjust until it seems fairly squared up. Then type info at the main menu to list the initial values to plug into the Chip-E Gamepad code as per step 6 to have a reasonable starting place.

The next upgrade is only necessary if your primary surface is hardwood/tile floor like I have. The hard plastic (I used PETG, but ABS and PLA have the same problem) tends to slip somewhat. That is what leftTrac and rightTrac are for. They are printed in ninjaflex and attached with double sided tape. I have not tested this upgrade on carpet or concrete.

No Mad Scientist trusts his assistant and you shouldn't trust E-Gor either. That is why he is outfitted with his own goPro-like camera. Of course a goPro would be too large, so I used an FPV camera (wolfwhoop wt05, although other companies make similar). The connector will have to be cut off, fed through the holes of the cameraHolder and HeadFPV, then new wires with jumpers soldered on. Make sure to use shrink wrap to cover the exposed wires. The positive can be plugged into the 3 or 5 volt on the shield, but not the VIN (or you will need to buy a new camera). I suggest the 3 volt because the camera will still get quite warm during use. An example video, checking out the kitchen floor cleaning, can be seen here: https://youtu.be/EeNrsZY1rzQ

To receive the video, there are many options including FPV googles (not recommended for anyone susceptible to motion sickness - see video above), wolfwhoop makes a receiver that can be plugged into a monitor or tv, and the ROTG01 (which I used to record the video) which can be attached to many phones and tablets and is available from many vendors.

To use the Dozer or the Cart, you will need a stabilizer and the newTop to mount it to. Yes, I realize a wheeled robot would be far better for this task. Even a quadraped or hexaped would work better. But where would be the challenge in that? So there are two versions of the stabilizers included, the first, which uses print in place ball joints was a very limited success. The second, using print in place u-joints, is much better, but still not perfect. I include both for people to experiment with and improve upon. There is still some minimal lateral sway especially when there is no load.

You will also need wheels. Two wheels for the Dozer and four wheels for the Cart. The tire part of the wheels are printed with nija- or semi- flex. I found that both worked well for traction on hardwood/tiled floor. I believe they will be fine for carpet and and concrete, but have not tested them. The bearings are 10mm in diameter and 4mm thick with a 3mm hole. I mounted these wheels with 3mm x 10mm screws that were left over from the Chip-E kit - they supply plenty of spares in this regard.

For the Dozer just print the Dozer and dozerMount (I attached using 3mm x 6mm screws, again left over from the build).

For the Cart, you will need two Trays, two backLegs, two frontLegs, and two wheelHolders (the backLegs have the wheelHolders already attached). To attach the frontLegs to the wheelHolders, use two more of the 10mm x 4mm bearings. Press the the center of the bearing on to the 3mm peg at the bottom of the front leg. Then press the bearing into the hole in top of the wheelHolder. Attach the legs with 3mm screws between 12mm and 18mm long.

To summarize the Summary, to build E-Gor you will need the following:

Chip-E kit from RobotGeek or equivalent mechanical and electronic components
All of the 3-D printed parts except the Head and the Top (to use Cart and Dozer)
HeadFPV
cameraHolder
newTop

To reduce slippage:

leftTrac
rightTrac

To use the Cart and/or Dozer:

Stabilizer

Cart:

Tray (2)
frontLeg (2)
rearLeg (2)
wheelHolder (2)
Wheel (4)
10mm x 4mm Bearing [3mm hole] (6)
3mm x 10mm screw (4)
3mm x 12-18mm screw (8)

Dozer:

Dozer
dozerMount
Wheel (2)
10mm x 4mm Bearin [3mm hole] (2)
3mm x 6mm screw (6)

Enjoy, but never trust, your E-Gor.

More, Why I Desiged This

A year and a half ago, I built a 3-D printer as a Christmas present to myself. What would take most people 8-10 hours took me 3 weeks because I could only work a little bit each day due to my back. But I enjoyed it and printed much, most of it from Thingiverse, frequently modifying something, but never enough, in my mind, to make it worthy of uploading.

In November, I bought a Prusa MK II kit and it again took a while to assemble. I printed many more things including several Otto robots for gifts last Christmas. In fact, the wheels and bearings were from failed experiments at developing inline skates for Otto [I should say, the code was more where the failure was]. I may take this back up for E-Gor at a later time. My idea for motion was based on cross-country skiing...

I also had the idea at the time of some type of camera, much like a goPro that skateboarders wear..

Skip forward to this spring where I am building and designing some drones, and then this Challenge comes along. A chance to use some of my experience, and dry wit, and try to return to the community that has given me so much.

While waiting for the kit, I considered what I knew from the docs and similarities to Otto. I knew the slippage issue would be the same, I knew an FPV camera would work (although I had to test longer running times to verify they could take it). But I wanted more. I wanted a challenge. So I decided to make it do actual work and push something, one of the most difficult operations possible.

I decided on the Dozer to retrieve crashed drones, since this could be actual, useful work. When showing a family friend an early version of the stabilizer and completed Dozer, he asked why not add a cart, so in late June the Cart design came to life.

But most of the time was spent on the stabilizer and much more time could be spent on it. It works, but not perfectly. It can even transport a cup of tea, mostly, but not completely, full. Otherwise there will be spills.

This is a simple fidget spinner kit that is composed of 100% 3D printable parts. Just print the 3 basic components (spinner shell, gear bearing and bearing caps) together at 100% infill, break the gear bearing free with a 5mm width hex key, assemble them together and it's done!

The bearing caps are concave on the inside to make the spinner easy to grip. No support is required.

For best results, you might want to loosen the gear bearing using a power drill or any similar device.

Notes:

  • If you intend to use this for small children, you might want to glue the parts together to prevent potential issues.

title: Adjustable Phone Stand (Fully Printable, No Supports)

description.text:
I designed this to be an adjustable smartphone stand that you can very finely adjust the viewing angle of your phone or small tablet. It's meant to be small and portable. It may not suit everyone's needs but I wanted something that I could easily travel with.

NOTE: The "flat screw" is a faster print than the "Alternate screw" but the alternate screw prints more cleanly. You only need to print one or the other.

To assemble:

  1. Slide the screw all the way in to the stand.
  2. Turn the screw until it is fully seated against the frame.
  3. Install the snap ring over the smooth part of the screw, against the inside of the frame, as depicted in the photos.

Note: This design can be scaled up to suit large tablets if you so choose.

UPDATE 03AUG2017: I have added a "Deep" version that should accommodate phones with thicker cases on them.

UPDATE 17JUL2017: I added an alternate screw design that prints on it's end. This should be easier to insert but will take much longer to print and won't be quite as strong. Strength shouldn't be needed for this design anyway.

Hatchbox Alpha

description.text:
The Chip-E Universal Expansion Kit (Chip-E UEK) is a set of replacement parts for the RobotGeek 'Chip-E' - Open Source Arduino 3D Printed Robot. The Chip-E UEK (Chip-E Universal Expansion Kit) was designed for the Chip-E Remix Chanage.

The Chip-E UEK was designed to add Makerbeam aluminum extrusions to the outside corners of the body. These 100mm Makerbeam extrusions replaces all the standoffs that were used to hold the body of the Chip-E together (the Arduino standoffs are still needed). The Chip-E UEK's Makerbeam extrusions offer convenient hard points mounts for other external mods and/or add-ons. Additionally, the operator now has the ability to get to any part within the Chip-E UEK by only removing 4 M3 bolts.

Design Project: N/A

====================================================================

Printed Parts needed:

1x Head_MB_Mod

1x Top_MB_Mod

1x Midsection_MB_Mod

1x Base_MB_Mod

1x Shoe_Left from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795648

1x Shoe_Right from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795648

1x Foot_Left from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795648

1x Foot_Right from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795648

====================================================================

Hardware Needed:

Part that are listed in the original Chip-E's Part List or The Chip-E Kit

Up to 15x M3 nuts with Up to 15x M3 6mm Square Head Bolts or Up to 15x M3 nuts with Up to 15x M3 6mm Wing Type Head Bolts

8x M3 Screws (I used M3x16 but use a minimum of a M3x12)

4x Makerbeam Extruded Aluminium Beams 100mm

====================================================================

Info on Building:

See the Build instructions for Chip-E Universal Expansion Kit REV 0.pdf for Build instructions.

====================================================================

Info on the Design:

Up until the weekend of July 8th and 9th, I was not planning on entering the Chip-E Remix Chanage. But after seeing Flying Chip-E and the very cool The Zip-E Chip-E, I thought to myself, "These technical designs would be a lot easier if the Chip-E had the flexibility that some of my Sci Oly designs do".

As such I set myself the goal of making a Chip-E that had at least one aluminum extrusion built in. It turned out that having 4 would give me even more versatility in the Chip-E UEK.

I am a big fan of the use of aluminum extrusion in my designs. They offer an easy way of attaching something new to a design after the fact, and orders of magnitude easier than go through all the steps of remaking or remixing the original design files. After adding in the Makerbeam, I think the Chip-E has become more valuable to me as it could be a platform for future Science Olympiad or other Robotic competitions. I can now tack on tools, and end-effectors to the Chip-E (UEK) as needed to meet rules, to complete tasks, or just for the fun or it.

On a side note, I left the slope on the head of the Chip-E UEK in the hopes that the robot would retain some of its character that the original Chip-E had. However, I have yet to decide if it is worth keeping or not. I may in the future Remix my Remix to remove the slope and give it a block head.

Below are the "Should Include" for the Chip-E Remix Challenge:

Explaining your changes:
As noted above, I have added Makerbeam Aluminum extrusions to the corners of the Chip-E. This offers three advantages over the original design:

  1. The user can access any level of the body by removing a maximum of 4 M3 screws.
  2. Creates hard point mounts for future mods and/or add-ons
  3. Removes and replaces the standoffs that where used to hold the body of the CHip-E together.

I hope that the Chip-E UEK means people that are not comfortable with or don't have the ability to work on other peoples CAD files can create mods for the platform.

How you remixed:
After importing and converting the *.step files that Robotgeeks included with the original Chip-E uploaded into something Fusion 360 can use, I started by figuring out how much space I could take away from the inside and still have the Chip-E be big enough for its hardware. It turned out I needed to leave as much space as I could so I did not interfere with the power plug, LCD, or battery.

As such, it was a lot easier to redesign the original body parts to hold about 1/2 of the Makerbeam and then extent the body left and right to make the Makerbeam flush with the edges of the body.

I then added the blocky corners to the head and base to allow for them to be attached to the Makerbeam with M3 screwes. Due to the limited hardware I had on hand, I designed the through hole corners to be compatible with the M3 x 16 screws I had on hand. This required me to thicken the Top (plate) to fill in the gap left by a missing 3 mm in the overall height of the Chip-E. I added walls to the bottom part of the Top Plate to allow for the Arduino standoffs to still function as designed.

Finally I added way to may holes into the midsection to allow for the midsection to be attached to the Makerbeam. This is not me just punching holes for the fun of it, I was trying to give the user of this design the flexibility to use any bolt pattern they want.

Any new skills you have given to Chip-E:
I gave Chip-E the ability to be expandable and modifiable without the person doing the changes having to completely redesign the body of the Clip-E.

Document the changes:
Noted Above

title: Reversible Hygrometer Humidity Meter Sensor Frame Holder Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have long since been in search of a good, simple frame to hold the cheap digital hygrometers that I use to monitor the humidity of my dry boxes for filament storage. There are a number of designs out there, but nothing really truly fit what I was looking for. I want elegant but simple with a few options.

So I finally broke down and designed my own. It is simple, orthogonal, doesn't use much material and gets the job done. I made the mounting tabs oversized so that they could be attached with tape or some other adhesive in addition to screws. I don't like the idea of drilling through my dry boxes, so this was important for me.

This holder is reversible so that you can mount the meter on the inside or outside of a surface. Some of the hygrometers have "remote" sensors on wires, so I allowed for wire holes as well, assuming the meter would be surface mounted on the outside of something.

There are 4 variations on the design included in the files. These are all possible combinations of with or without mounting tabs and wire holes.

Here are the links to the two different types of meters you see in the photos:
Digital Hygrometer Temperature Meter
Digital Hygrometer Temperature Meter with Remote Sensor

Please post pictures of your makes, requests and comments. I love hearing from the community.

ENJOY!

Please note the license of this thing. This design, or any derivative of this design, cannot be used commercially without my prior consent. I don't mind if you want to remix and use this design in your other projects, but please give a link back to this original creation, and license your remix under the same license. I love sharing my designs for free, but I don't want them used improperly for commercial purposes.

Slotted base half inch post holder. The holes running up along the body are intended to be tapped for 1/4-20 thumb screws to lock the post in place. The slot in the base is size for clearance to slide along a 1/4-20 screw mounted into a standard 1" x 1" spacing optical breadboard/table.

You'll need to run a 1/4-20 tap through the holes in the body. Holes oriented in this manner tend to sag and shrink so the tap will be a tight fit. This is intended in an effort to extend the life of the holes.

Intended to be mounted onto standard optical breadboards and isolation tables. As such, the slot is specced to freely move along a 1/4-20 screw. At about 2.5" long the slot is always within reach of a mounting hole on a standard 1" spaced breadboard.
The through hole on both versions is significantly oversized at 0.520" to compensate for surface roughness and shrinkage that occurs during printing with PLA. I'd recommend a test print of a single piece before attempting a batch.

This makes a quick and easy replacement for standard post holders and attachable bases. Whether you need components for additional student groups or you simply need a part while awaiting an order of commercial cage components.

title: Mini Table Saw v1 - Direct Drive
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mini Hand Powered Table Saw - Direct Drive Version

"A fun and inconvenient way to cut a slice of bread in half that only takes 10 times longer than using a regular knife."

Check out the video to see it in action. https://youtu.be/jo2JSW73ru8

This is the Direct Drive version of my Mini Hand Powered Table Saw. It is operated by rotating the crank towards yourself to cause the blade to turn in the same direction.

I printed everything without supports except the Crank assembly and the Top. My Monoprice Select Mini printer was even able to print the Table Bottom without supports, though just barely. Some of the layers began curling under before it was able to bridge the gap and close the tops of the largest openings.

The half circle opening in the Crank is the hardest to clean out. I eventually added a drop of glue to keep it on the Crank shaft otherwise it would fall off after rigorous cranking.

When attempting to cut something, the Table should be held in place with a small clamp or a second pair of helpful hands.

You can find the v2 Two Gear version here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430770
and the v3 Four Gear Version here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2435292

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS (See Exploded View Picture)

Parts may need some clean up for the pieces to fit together.

Add the Handle over the thin part of the Crank. This should fit tightly enough not to come off but loose enough that you can turn it in place.

Slide the Blade onto the Blade Shaft and then angle the left end of the shaft down through the Table Bottom putting the end through the small hole on the left. Once it is in you can slide the right end of the shaft through the hole on the right. Add a Washer to the left end of the shaft and the Crank to the right end of the shaft. The Washer should fit very snugly.

Add the Table Top. If needed, the Blade be adjusted along the shaft.

And you are ready to go!

title: Mini Table Saw v2 - Two Gears
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mini Hand Powered Table Saw - Geared Version

"A fun and inconvenient way to cut a slice of bread in half that only takes 10 times longer than using a regular knife."

Check out the video to see it in action. https://youtu.be/YdjeBk1n6ic

This is the Geared version of my Mini Hand Powered Table Saw. Unlike the Direct Drive version, this one is operated by rotating the crank forward to cause the blade to turn towards you. The gear ratio is also about 1:1.5 so for every turn of the crank you make, the blade will rotate 1.5 turns.

Like the previous version, I printed everything without supports except the Crank assembly and the Top. My Monoprice Select Mini printer was even able to print the Table Bottom without supports, though just barely. Some of the layers began curling under before it was able to bridge the gap and close the tops of the largest openings.

You also need to print 3 of the washers.

The half circle opening in the Crank is the hardest to clean out. I eventually added a drop of glue to keep it on the Crank shaft otherwise it would fall off after rigorous cranking.

When attempting to cut something, the Table should be held in place with a small clamp or a second pair of helpful hands.

You can find the v1 Direct Drive version here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430760
and the v3 Four Gear version here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2435292

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS (See Exploded View Picture)

Parts may need some clean up for the pieces to fit together.

Add the Handle over the thin part of the Crank. This should fit tightly enough not to come off but loose enough that you can turn it in place.

Slide the Large Gear onto the Crank Shaft and then angle the left end of the shaft down through the Table Bottom putting the end through the small lower hole on the left. Once it is in you can slide the right end of the shaft through the hole on the right. Add a Washer to the left end of the shaft and the Crank to the right end of the shaft. The Washers should fit very snugly.

Slide the Small Gear and the Blade onto the Blade Shaft and position it into the two small upper holes like you did with the Crank Shaft. Then add a washer to each end.

Add the Table Top. If needed, the Blade and the two Gears can all be adjusted along the shafts.

And you are ready to go!

description.text:
This is the second version of the SFX Rescue Robot. Unlike the other version, this model is not modular but is a lot smaller, and is capable of turning around inside itself.

The robot's files are on Thingiverse as it is a requirement of the Open Academic Robot Kit for everything to be open source and publicly available.

All of the correct measurements (in mm) can be found in the images. You will need to scale them as they were designed in Sketchup using mm but Makerbot Desktop and Cura both assume the measurements are in inches.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

20-100%

Notes:

Most of the parts are capable of being printed on most Makerbot 3D Printers, however due to the nature of some of the pieces being rather large, I printed these pieces on an Ultimaker 2 in ABS filament, using a mix of acetone and scrap ABS filament to adhere the print to the bed.

The belt was printed in flexible filament with no raft/brim and stretches around the wheels with the cutout in the middle. I didn't have much success with the belt so it probably won't get used in the Robocup competition, but your mileage may vary. Side note - the belt has to be printed at 100% infill otherwise the flexible filament (ninjaflex) doesn't work properly- at least that's what I found. If you use something else and it works, that's fine as well. I would just reccomend 100% infill in order to not waste your time.

Most of the stl files do not need supports, however the main body (robot.stl) needs supports for the servo hole cutouts.

A laser cut case for a raspberry pi 3 and the 7" touchscreen.

It's designed for 1/8" acrylic but 3mm will work if you cut more pieces where you need them. All lines are cut.

All holes are for M3 bolts -- the smaller holes are meant to be tapped. The length of the bolts will depend on the thickness of your acrylic and the number of layers you use.

The layer closest to the screen isn't bolted to anything and is just held by pressure. The construction has the outer set of holes used to hold the acrylic together while the inner set of holes goes all the way through to the touch screen.

I'm not in love with the feet but they work. They block some of the USB ports - I'm working on a better design for the feet.

Setup:

The Touchscreen and Raspi are set up according to their instructions. I soldered the power lines to the Raspi but it'll work with a header. The ribbon cable snakes through the back of the case.

title: A Dodecahedron Speaker for Desktop Printers

description.text: A dodecahedron speaker can be a useful tool in acoustics research, and is definitely a fun toy to pull out at parties. They are available commercially, but pretty expensive. Some people build their own, but the odd compound angles and the high degree of accuracy and precision required in the parts make for challenging work with manual tools. It's a perfect job for a 3D printer. Total cost for parts and materials is just under $100. That includes speakers, hardware, wires, cable, plastic filament - everything. January 16, 2015 I recently made my original SketchUp files for these parts publicly available at this link: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/collection.html?id=uc448c896-3f80-41d2-a0d3-0c2685e74d84 These may be useful to anyone who wants to adapt the design to their own equipment.

The high symmetry of the dodecahedron is amenable to a modular design, and this one consists of four basic parts: the face modules, the vertex plugs, the edge gaskets, and the bezels. The speaker grilles are made from hardware store window screen cloth installed in the bezels using rubber spline and a screen roller tool, just like a residential window screen. The assembled speaker array weighs 5.6 lbs, not counting the cable, and measures 7.5" across, from face to face, and 8.6" from point to point. The speakers are wired in a hybrid series-parallel circuit that brings the total array impedance to about 10 ohms (again not counting the cable) which should be a comfortable load for most amplifiers. Non-printed parts ("vitamins")

comments.text: Thanks, and great to hear from you.  I am quite aware of your Sputnik 17 project.  I have followed the Thingiverse RSS feed religiously for years, or at least I did until I decided to enter this silly Instructables contest, and then every awesome thing that came up on T-verse started to undermine my confidence:  surely my precious dodec speaker concept could never beat THAT.  Your thing #21272 was the straw that broke the camel's back, and I stopped reading the feed for the sake of my own rapidly fraying nerves.  Your design is easier to make than mine and includes a generator script so you can make various sizes and aren't locked in to using a particular speaker model.  This is something I wanted to do, but didn't really have the time to figure out with my limited OpenSCAD skills. I was sure you were going to enter Sputnik 17 in the Make It Real challenge and kick my ass with it.  It looks, now, like you didn't, as I far as I've been able to tell, for which I am very grateful. And even if you did, and I missed it, the deadline has passed, it's out of my hands,  and I'm happy to let things shake out as they will over on Instructables.  And I can go back to enjoying the T-verse RSS feed and finally say to you what I wanted to say when I first saw your project:  Beautiful work!

comments.text: I made this axis by scaling it up in Cura to fit a NEMA23 stepper. Obviously, the holes for the linear rails were wrong after scaling, so I printed parametric linear bearings to fit the holes and 10mm linear guide rods, I also printed parametric bushings to fit the guide rods in the end pieces. I made an acetal leadscrew bearing to fit the 1/2" x 10tpi leadscrew. Have it mstly assembled except for screws to clamp the linear bearings in place. I've been running the carriage back and forth with a drill for testing. Next is to mount the stepper and set up an Arduino with CNC shield to test.
