description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZghpAGHpL9g

This is a Chip-E remix, but created completely from scratch from parts I had on hand. In 3 days. It uses the Chip-E biped concept and much of it's design, but it uses smaller Corona 929MG 9 gram servos and an Arduino Pro Mini. I think it's about 70% the size of the real Chip-E.

I designed the duck in MeshMixer, and all of the mechanical components in Fusion 360. To get the duck to connect to the mechanical bits, I created a negative form of the body cavity including screw holes in Fusion 360. I exported that body as an STL file, which I then imported into MeshMixer and subtracted it from the duck body. The body was split into main body, head, and beak to reduce support requirements, and to allow me to print an orange beak. :)

The beak and head parts were glued onto the main body using acetone. I also acetone smoothed the body, but the results were not great. The eyes were painted on with acrylic paint.

The mechanical components were designed completely in Fusion 360 by measuring the servos I had on hand using a digital caliper. I used the standard mounting screws that came with the servos, and the standard servo horns and wheels to connect to the feet and legs.

The electronics are built from an Arduino Pro Mini clone mounted on perfboard. There is no fancy circuitry to speak of, just breakouts for the servos. There is one current limiting resistor for the buzzer.

I intended the duck to be powered by a small 2 cell LiPo battery, but I did not have one on hand and could not get one quickly. So instead I've added a 5mm power jack on the bottom plate and power it with a 5v wall plug for now. A small battery should fit on top of the circuit board.

Printer:

OrdBot Hadron

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

various

Notes:

The body was printed with sparse supports, 2 outer shells, and 10% infill using 0.3mm layer height. The head and beak were similar but did not require supports.

The feet, legs, and bottom plate were printed with 100% infill for strength using 0.3mm layer height. The legs benefit from a very small amount of support under the pivot pin where the foot attaches, but it may not be necessary.

Build Instructions

Start by zeroing your servos. I did this with the walk example, but removed the contents of the loop function. Flash this edited version and it will zero your servos on startup. Leave it powered and it will hold the servos in the zero position.

Next screw the hip servos in the bottom plate. The leg parts will mount on these servo shafts using a the round control arm attachments from the corona servo. I cut off some standard mounting screws to attach the disk through the leg.

Mount the leg on the hip servo shaft being careful to keep it straight and not turn the servo. If you accidentally move it, re-run the zero process and try again.

Next, mount the ankle servos in the feet using the screws that come with the servos. The servo shaft should line up with the pivot hole on the back of the foot.

Using a control horn from the servo and the shaft fastening screw, mount the foot on the bottom of the leg. It should be perpendicular to the leg.

Next mount your PCB on the studs on the top of the bottom plate. I had to mount it upside-down to get it all to fit nicely. There is enough space between the hip servos for the Arduino Pro Mini.

Glue the beak and head to the body. If you printed them with ABS, you can use acetone as glue. If PLA, you can use super glue or epoxy.

Complete the power and piezo wiring. I'll leave this as an exercise for the reader. Check the Chip-E documentation for help.

Finally, mount the duck body on the bottom plate using 4 servo mounting screws.

Quack!

Much of the design was parametric in Fusion 360 using measurements from my calipers. As the design progressed, I used less parametric variables because the file was getting complex.

Mixing MeshMixer and Fusion 360 was an interesting experiment. By using boolean operations and STL files expored from Fusion, I was able to achieve both an organic sculpted look, and a mechanically accurate mounting structure on the inside.

This is the negative "mold" that I created in Fusion 360 and subtracted from the duck in MeshMixer.

description.text:
Just my own version of cable organizer for my Tevo Little Monster delta printer. There are others out there but one that was easy to open and I wanted to test printing this lip design from a 3d printer.

I did use a 0.15mm layer height so that the hooks print half way decent. I would recommend scaling it up a bit but it worked for me as you can see from the pictures.

Oh, this was designed to print in the convex position and without any support.

I wanted a CR2032 storage holder that would have some better retention than other ones I've seen up here so I made this. The batteries snap in with a bit of force, and then you can eject them by pushing on the bottom.

Print with supports on the underside for best results.

title: PokeSpinner - The Pokeball Fidget Spinner for B127/608

description.text:
This is a remix that serves for two different goals:

  1. Remix for a smaller size fidget spinner for B127 ball bearing (12.7mm Dia x 4.7mm Bore)

  2. Normal size fidget spinner for 608 ball bearing (easier to make)
    • modification that enables parts that are easier to print/assemble than original model
    • modification that opens more space for weight, one might want to use, e.g., glass or metal ball instead of a nut
    • Hemispheres have more even wall thicknesses - result is more even color when using dilute pigments (white) that transmit some light

To make smaller size spinner use these files:

  • PokeSpinner_BearingCap_12p74laakeri.STL
  • PokeSpinner_Body_12p74laakeri.STL
  • PokeSpinner_Button_12p74laakeri.STL
  • PokeSpinner_Hemisphere_oma_v2_12p74laakeri.STL

To make normal size spinner remix use these files

  • PokeSpinner_BearingCap.STL
  • PokeSpinner_Body_oma.STL or PokeSpinner_Body_oma_lasipallolle.STL
  • PokeSpinner_Button.STL
  • PokeSpinner_Hemisphere_oma_v2.STL

This replica of the famous BT700 armoured vehicle represents a mid production vehicle. Earlier vehicles had less powerful guns while the latter vehicles had a re-designed turret for added protection.
The tank relies on its inbuilt nuke generator which is set on the mid right side and powers the long axis generation column. The wheels are all independently powered by the engines above them, and this leaves much of the vehicle interior open for use as a troop transporter. The rear hatch is the main access, but the turret top also includes the commanders cupola and hatch. Designed as a tank which could use both tracks or wheels, the track option proved so problematic that the option was dropped.
The tanks proved to be very useful in a dozen planetary battles over the last six decades, but as the Aliens began to use more powerful hover vehicles, and the BT700 was deemed too vulnerable to use on the front line and were replaced with improved vehicles.

Mare Do Well from MLP.
The hat is a separate piece as printing in place wouldn't work without a lot of support, it looks way better like this - printed flat and then carefully using a hot bed to gently bend the edges to make it look floppy. The hat slides off fairly easily, you may want to add a small blob of blu-tac.
This is best printed with a raft as the hat sticks to the bed and is really hard to get off otherwise, and the legs will probably detach from the bed without it.
I've designed this so that no supports should be required.

title: DDC Adjustable angle GoPro Session protective case mount

description.text:
This protective case can be rotated so you can set the desired angle for every location you want to fly in.

It can even be mounted pointing backwards, so you can record what happens behind the quad.

The base is fixed to the to frame using zip ties, and the camera housing, once you set the desired angle, is fixed to the base by another two zip ties. There are five holes in the base, to suit different frames and case positions.

Camera housing has been rebuilt a little thicker to better protect the camera. Might need some tweeking in the front if the front border get into view...

Printed in NinjaFlex at 20% infill.

remixed_from.author: pindemand
remixed_from.title: Prusa i4 X linear Rail support

title: OrangePI Lite built into Sunhokey Prusa i4 and other printer modifications

description.text:
3D printer for me is just one more tool like screwdriver or dremel. And (sure) very interesting project by itself. So many things were done with Sunhokey Prusa i4 for the past few months while I own it. This post is to summarize all changes (improvements?).

What was done:

  • Second Y-axis rail inspired by pindemand: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1832499
  • Control board and chassis active cooling: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2423258
  • Circular fan duct with BLTouch sensor mount and additional lightening: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2495004
  • Anti-backlash nuts integration inside X-axis holders: holder block was drilled out to 12mm from the bottom and 14mm from the top
  • Additional print area lightning: printer is installed in built-in cupboard so this is required
  • Z-axis screw rods stabilizer
  • Bed auto leveling with (clone of) BL-Touch sensor
  • Control panel moved down as printer is placed high enough https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2671526
  • Print head cable chain: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2422058
  • Octoprint server running on OrangePI Lite PC integrated inside chassis so I can not only completely control printer remotely but even compile and upload printer firmware
  • Octoprint-controlled power relay allow powering on/off all printer hardware leaving active OrangePI PC only
  • Default power switch was replaced with 3-state switch (always on / off / controlled by Octoprint) and moved to front panel
  • Octoprint-connected web camera installed in cupboard for remote control and time-lapse
  • Filament runout sensor

Latest version of Marlin firmware, customized for BLTouch clone, connected as shown on pictures may be found here: http://aeinc.ru/i4/

BLTouch sensor clone I use: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1set-BLTouch-Auto-Bed-Leveling-Touch-Sensor-BLTouch-Classic-BLTouch-C-with-cables-Spare-parts-for/32787946802.html

comments.author: k0l9khv

comments.text:
Sorry, Is this a question and description of your situation? Do you use original BLTouch sensor with firmware referenced above?
If yes then answer will be:
I use a clone of BLTouch sensor (non-original one that is Marlin developed for). This sensor behaves slightly different so I have to patch firmware to commit these differences. So if you just used my version of firmware withoriginal BLTouch then you need to abandon these changes. And this may be done by replacing my changed version of "Conditionals_LCD.h" file with original file you may find in "Original" folder of all zips attached.

description.text:
This is the main body frame for a T-Copter
This is a project and i will be posting more pictures
This will accommodate a receiver, a 100mmx 25x 35mm battery and 3 ESCs on the lower piece (the piece without the square holes) and a kk2(.0 or .1) board on the top. i am using 1/2 inch square wooden dowels for the arms and NTM 800kv outrunners for the motors and HobbyKing 30amp speed controllers.

These protective trimmer covers fit any brushcutter blade that is below 4mm of thickness.
You also need rubber band to join all three pieces together.
I used 1.75mm pla and printing temperature 210°C.

description.text:
The University of Montana's iconic Grizzly Bear that flanks the western side of the oval.  The sculpture  was designed by Rudy Autio, one of the fathers of modern ceramics, who sculpted the bear in clay.  It was cast in bronze and set in place in 1968.  
I scanned it with 123D Catch on a day with horrible sun glare on one side.  I'm amazed that it worked.  
Part of my "originals" MFA thesis work. More information on the project can be seen here: benmalouf.com/originals
Print with support on.

author: Tontonmox

print_settings.Notes:: Note

title: iPhone 5s Bicycle Mount Rework for iPhone 6 or 7 With Cover

description.text:
I found this fantastic model for a bicycle mount for my iPhone 5s, but realized that it only holds the phone without a case (not big enough for case). So after I upgraded to a 7 and my girlfriend to a 6 (which are both the same size) I decided to finally rework this model in Trimble Sketchup to be able to hold the phone with its casing.

I already tested the model and it works great. At first it may seem as if the phone will fall out, but believe me it supports it fantastically.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1.3mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed the model with a 2 layer shell, top and bottom, but realized that the ideal may be to go for 3 or even 4 layer to ensure a cleaner look and also a more sturdy model.

Note - The mount and case may need some sanding afterwards for a perfect fit.
Final printed product with minor sanding afterwards iPhone 7 fits perfectly

title: Talisman Giant Gold Coin (board game) Decoration

description.text:
I was trying to recreate gold coins for Talisman (as there seems to be too few at every game we play).
But in the end the gold coins are simply too small to have them printed out in 3D.
So, I decided to use it as a 'Giant Coin'. Purely decorative ! (could be a nice 'medal' or 'belt-buckle' for example .. up to you !) .. just scale it up, and print !

I can only say how gratefull I am that people share stuff so others can change it. So if you're keen to that principle, don't go making money on what people share for free !

-enjoy-
